_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan (RMP) Executive Summary

The Premcor Refining Group (Premcor), Memphis, Tennessee (Valero Memphis Refinery is part of the Valero Energy Corporation) - RMP Facility ID#1000 0015 8107 
September 2006, re-submission for the startup of a new process unit - Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel Hydrotreater, DHT-18. 

Premcor submitted an update of the RMP in April 2006, to make changes to Section 1, Registration Information.  The information changed included the following:
     Facility name
     Parent company name
     Facility location address (the facility did not relocate, but the address of the administration building where personnel are located changed).
     The address of the administration building is 2385 Riverport Road, Memphis, TN, 38109
     The person responsible for the RMP implementation 
     The emergency contact
     Date of the last safety inspection

Site Information

Premcor operates a variety of processes to produce high quality petroleum products from raw crude oil.  All refinery process units are currently managed under the PSM Standard; therefore, these process units are currently managed as RMP Program Level 3 processes.  The refinery has a thoroughly-trained, experienced, safety-motivated workforce that has achieved an outstanding safety record.  The refinery is in full compliance with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.

Premcor has a longstanding commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the time, money, and effort invested in training personnel and promoting safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. Safety tools include engineering controls, real time process monitoring, level, pressure, and temperature alarms, leak detection systems, and automatic and manual mitigation systems. If a release does occur, our trained

personnel will respond quickly and effectively to control and contain the release.

To comply with the RMP standard we have focused upon the following:

Maintaining the management system established by PSM
Adapting the PSM management system to address RMP
Performing the hazard assessments
Compiling the data elements
Communicating with the public concerning RMP issues

Public Communication of RMP 

Premcor (Williams Refining at the time) assumed a leadership role in organizing a community wide-RMP Symposium that took place April 13, 1999, at the Agricenter International.  The Memphis/Shelby County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) was the lead agency.  Twelve area companies, numerous federal, state, and local regulatory and emergency response agencies participated in the symposium.  Each company or agency prepared a booth with informational literature and displays.  Persons ready and willing to discuss RMP, safety programs, or answer public questions staffed the booths.  Expert speakers, emergency response equipment, and live demonstrations of Shelter-in-Place and HAZMAT response were also featured.  Approximately 600 people attended the symposium.

The refinery has been working with our Community Advisory Panel (CAP), which meets monthly, to identify effective means for communicating RMP/Safety information to our immediate neighboring community.  CAP members have provided many helpful suggestions, and have offered to distribute our RMP-related printed material at various venues in the community.  Premcor and the CAP members agree that RMP/Safety communication should be an ongoing effort.

Hazard Assessment Results - Identification of Scenarios

Release scenario results were estimated using the RMPlanner software published by JBF Associates.  The software calculates estimated distances to the endpoint based on the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) "Lookup" Tables.  Hydrofluoric (HF) acid is the only covered toxic that is present in the refinery in a thre

shold quantity.  The largest inventory of RMP flammables is in the LPG spheres.

Five Year Accident History

Premcor has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years.  No incident has resulted in offsite effects (deaths, injuries, significant property damage, evacuations, shelter-in-place, or environmental damage) as defined by EPA's RMP guidelines (RMP-covered process and RMP-covered chemicals).  During the past five years, the following minor releases have occurred:

*Two propane releases
*Three Hydrogen sulfide releases
*Five Hydrofluoric acid releases (three of these releases also contained flammable mixtures)

Each incident was carefully investigated to determine the cause of the incident and what actions to take to prevent similar incidents from occurring.  All of these releases were detected and contained within the plant with no off site impact.  Information concerning these minor releases have been submitted in the RMP data elements. 

In the accident history data elements for 1999-2006, some of the release amounts are estimates. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps

The following summary describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program at Premcor.  RMP-regulated processes at the refinery are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  Therefore, this summary will address each of the OSHA PSM elements.

The Health, Safety, and Environment (HS&E) Department oversees compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119, the PSM standard.  The department has developed a management system for satisfying the requirements of each of the 14 elements that comprise the PSM standard.  Where appropriate, a time frame is specified for completion of the necessary action.  The program is audited periodically to evaluate its effectiveness.  The management system is intended to accomplish the following:

* Describe the requirements of each paragraph of 1910.119
* Describe how each requirement will b

e satisfied
* Establish responsibilities for compliance action
* Ensure that all compliance actions are documented

Employee Participation

The HS&E Department leads the overall PSM effort.  Each refinery department is responsible for ensuring employee participation within the department.  The management system policy for each PSM element identifies responsibilities that are more specific.

*The refinery PSM program was developed with the direct participation and involvement of employees from all levels and departments in the refinery.

*Teams assembled for pre-startup safety reviews, HAZOPs, and incident investigations are composed of employees representing a broad spectrum of disciplines and experiences.

*The Joint Health and Safety Committee meets monthly to address all safety concerns that employees have that have not been addressed after work orders have been written and concerns generated in previous meetings.

*Management Hazard Assessment Team meets once a month to audit areas, and practices based on current injury and audit trends, Safety Committee recommendations and business needs.

*Central Safety Committee focuses on accident trends, agenda items brought forth by all committees and current activities of the PSM, Safety & Health Department.

*Safety & Health Policy Committee addresses new policies, modify existing policies, and recommend modifications.

*Contractor Safety Committee concentrates on communicating and getting contractors involved with monthly audits and making them part of the Valero Safety Program.

*Employees are encouraged to express ideas and concerns about process safety to their first line supervisors, superintendents, managers, or directors.

*Employees also participate in:  Process Hazard Analysis, Job Safety Analysis, Safety Meetings, and the Employee Safety Suggestion System.  The Writer / Trainers are also involved in both writing operating instructions and training employees.

Process Safety Information

Premcor compiles safety

information pertaining to the highly hazardous materials used or produced at the facility, the technology of the processes, and the equipment used.  Safety information is readily available, and is updated when changes are made, in accordance with management of change procedures.  A variety of technical documents are used to facilitate safe operation of the processes.  The documents address limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  The HS&E Department oversees the generation, management, and tracking of PSM related information.  The appropriate department, such as operations, maintenance, engineering, or inspection handles specific types of information.

*Most process safety information required by the PSM standard is available in the PSM database located on the refinery local area network.  For information not found in the database, a referral to its location is provided.  The majority of information not housed by the HS&E Department can be found in the engineering/technical department or in the mechanical integrity department.  

*Manuals containing operating procedures and process unit descriptions are available online in the PSM database, and in hard copy at several locations.  Operating Instructions are certified annually.

*Material safety data sheets for all products and chemicals used or produced at the refinery are available from the PSM database or on the company intranet MSDS website.

*Piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) for a process unit can be found in the control room and Operations Superintendent's office for that unit.  Refinery wide drawings are located in the drafting department.

*Documentation of pre-startup safety reviews, incident investigations, management of change, etc. is available online.

Process Hazard Analysis

Premcor conducts scheduled evaluations of the safety of all processes and related facilities within its boundary limits to ensure safe opera

tion and prevent the catastrophic release of hazardous materials.  Potential offsite consequences are considered as part of this evaluation.  The refinery currently uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) method of analysis, using the framework of the HAZOP computer program PHA Pro 6 located on the refinery intranet network.  Each analysis is conducted by a cross-functional team and facilitated by someone familiar with both the refinery and HAZOP methodology.  The team typically includes an operator from the covered process, a PSM facilitator, an engineer, maintenance, and instrumentation personnel.  Other technical or supervisory personnel may sit in on the evaluation when their expertise is needed.

Beginning in 2006, an outside consultant has been included during each HAZOP to perform a Level of Protection Analysis (LOPA) as part of the HAZOP team.  This allows the refinery to determine appropriate safety integrity levels (SIL) for the unit on which the HAZOP is being conducted.  This also meets the requirements of ISA S84.01.  By performing a LOPA analysis, the Memphis Refinery is moving ahead of the industry by performing this analysis before it is required by standard.

As safety concerns are evaluated, they are rated according to probability and consequence.  
All concerns are documented as part of the HAZOP process.  Safety concerns that warrant action are formally documented as recommendations, and passed on to an individual or department that will be responsible for resolution.  The HS&E Department tracks recommendations until they are resolved.  Documentation of the hazard analysis is accessible from the PSM database on the refinery local area network.  A hard copy of the PHA is maintained in the HS&E Department.

HAZOP results are periodically updated and revalidated to help ensure that process controls and / or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five

years and will continue until the process is no longer operating.  The results of these updates are documented and retained.  Update findings are forwarded to management for consideration.  Final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.  The HS&E Department is responsible for scheduling HAZOPs, preparing the final HAZOP report, communicating the findings and recommendations to the appropriate departments, and for following up on recommendations to ensure their completion.  Department managers ensure the participation of their employees on the HAZOP team. 

Facility siting is an integral part of the HAZOP.  The facility maintains a facility siting plan and map.

Operating Procedures

The refinery has developed and compiled a comprehensive set of operating procedures to provide instruction in the safe operation of refinery processes.  Procedures must provide a reliable and consistent reference for all phases of process operations including 1) unit startup, 2) normal operations, 3) temporary operations, 4) emergency shutdown, 5) normal shutdown, 6) initial startup of a new process, 7) emergency operations, and 8) startups following an abnormal or emergency shutdown.

Writers from each process unit, the laboratory, and the tank farm develop the procedures with input from engineers, supervisors, and other operators.  Before publication each procedure is reviewed by supervisors, engineers, and management for accuracy, consistency, and completeness.  In addition, each procedure is subject to editorial review to ensure readability.  All operating procedures are available through the PSM database and in hard copy.  Each procedure contains procedure steps, operating parameters and limits, safety and health hazard information, safety control measures, and assignment of responsibility for performing the procedure.  Operating procedures are kept current through the management of change process.

Operations, Engineering, and HS&E Departments bear responsibility for

by equipment failure and/or human error.  In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Premcor has safety features on many units to help 1) contain/control a release, 2) quickly detect a release, and 3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

* Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
* HF detectors with alarms
* Hydrogen Sulfide detectors with alarms
* Personal Hydrogen Sulfide detectors worn while in the refinery
* LPG alarms

Release Containment/Control

* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated)
* Emergency shutdown system
* Hydrofluoric acid dump tank
* Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation
* Atmospheric relief devices

Release Mitigation

* Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
* Deluge system for Alky Unit
* Trained emergency response personnel
* Personal protective equipment
* Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel

Emergency Response Program Information

Prevention is the best emergency plan.  Refinery operations are always conducted to minimize the chance of encountering emergencies.  When prevention fails, however, preparedness is the key to effective emergency response.  The Memphis Refinery maintains a written emergency response plan to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan consists of procedures and guidelines for responding to various emergencies, including release of a hazardous substance, fire or explosion.  The emergency response program addresses the following:

* Implementation of the Incident Command System (ICS)
* Scope of incident - Level I vs. Level II
* Level I incidents managed/controlled by the Area or Shift Supervisor. 
* Level II incidents managed/controlled by the refinery General Manager.  This lev

developing, reviewing, and approving operating procedures.  The Operations Department is responsible for correctly implementing operating procedures.

Training

Premcor has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees first receive basic training in refinery operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator (writer-trainer) to learn process-specific duties and tasks. Operators may work independently only after showing (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) adequate knowledge to perform job duties and tasks in a safe manner.

The training program addresses:
* Initial training - for new employees
* OSHA-mandated training - for all employees, covering topics such as hazard communication, process chemistry, refinery technology, emergency response, etc. 
* Progression training - for all employees moving up in job classification
* Refresher training - for all employees, covering new equipment and processes, and keeping knowledge and expertise up-to-date.

Employee training is an ongoing effort covering a variety of subjects.  Depending upon the subject, training may be preformed one-on-one, in a classroom setting, or using the computer-based training modules.  All training is documented and credited to the employee's personal record.  Where required, employees are tested to document participation and to confirm the employee understands the subject matter.  Any employee may view his individual training record by making a request to the Safety Department Administrative Assistant or the Training Department.  

The Safety Department is responsible for implementing the safety training program.  

The Training Department is responsible for operations new-hire training and refresher training.

Contractors

Premcor has developed a Contractor Safety Program to satisfy and exceed PSM guidelines by extending plant safety requirements to non-Premcor employee

s working within the refinery.  The Program is intended to maintain a plant-wide, consistent level of safe work performance. The HS&E Department is responsible for enforcing the Contractor Safety Program.  Such enforcement involves not only the contractor's responsibilities, but also Premcor's obligations under paragraph (h) of the PSM standard.  This program has resulted in the contractors at this site going 2524 days (as of 9/22/06) without a lost time accident.  The Contractor Safety Program includes the following:

* Requires contract bidders to provide information on accident rates and the contractor's safety programs.
* Requires the contractor to verify each employee's knowledge of job safety, craft skills, and equipment operation before assignment to onsite work.
* Restricts bid requests to those contractors who have satisfied minimum requirements.  Those requirements include reviewing of their OSHA 300 log, a documented drug screening program, comprehensive "Safety Action Plan," and English fluency for employees performing safety-sensitive work.  Contractors supply information on ISNETWORLD and receive a rating which is used to determine if they can become an approved contractor.  Contractor employees working in the refinery must comply with the requirements for 8 hours of specific safety training conducted through the Tennessee Valley Training Center or a reciprocal safety training center.
* Establishes pre-job meetings, pre-job safety orientation conference, and site-specific orientation before actual work begins to ensure that the contractor and contract employees fully understand the safety policies and requirements of the Memphis Refinery.  Contractors are expected to follow the Memphis Refinery Safe Work Practices.
* Assigns ultimate responsibility to contractors for their employees' safety.  Safety responsibility covers maintaining safe work conditions, control of unsafe acts, holding safety meetings, and accident investigation.
* Requires periodic au

dits to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their responsibilities under OSHA 1910.119.
* Establishes access control (card access system) for the process areas.
*Provides contractor specific orientation to the facility where hazards and emergency response is covered.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

Premcor conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) any time new equipment or modifications to existing equipment change the associated process safety information.  The review is intended to verify and document that all aspects of the equipment's design, construction and operation have been evaluated, and to certify that the equipment can be placed in operation. The PSSR team uses checklists and field verification of construction to examine all aspects of readiness.  The PSSR is the final step in the construction or installation of new or modified equipment before the equipment is placed in service.  The review addresses 1) design and construction, 2) maintenance and inspection, 3) procedures, and 4) training.

Mechanical Integrity

1910.119 (j) requires employers to take specific measures to "maintain ongoing integrity of process equipment."  These measures include following OEM guidelines for equipment maintenance and repair, training in maintenance activities, an inspection and testing program, safe and timely correction of equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance in fabrication, installation, and spare parts.  The Maintenance and Engineering Departments are responsible for the administration of the Mechanical Integrity Program of the Memphis Refinery.  Responsibility for specific aspects of mechanical integrity rests with the appropriate group - mechanical, instrument/controls, or inspection.  The Memphis Refinery's Mechanical Integrity Program accomplishes the following:

* Establishes responsibility for various aspects of the mechanical integrity program, divided among three groups - mechanical, instrument/controls, or inspection.  
* Requires procedure

s for the management of each of the three mechanical integrity groups.  The procedures must include a description of the group organization, standards for the development of procedures, a description of quality assurance measures, a written description of employee and contract employee training, a description of document controls, and requirements for periodic compliance audits.    
* Sets general operation and maintenance training requirements for maintenance employees.
* Sets guidelines for the conduct and documentation of process equipment inspection and testing. 
* Requires safe and timely correction of equipment deficiencies.
* Assures integrity and quality in the suitability, installation, and maintenance of equipment.

Work is performed under the supervision of a maintenance craft foreman.  Maintenance personnel follow industry standards and equipment specifications during maintenance activities.  Written safety procedures are followed for specific job tasks (i.e. line openings). A Job Safety Analysis (JSA) is conducted for all maintenance jobs that are non-routine or maybe different due to variables in the operation (i.e. Hot Taps or work on Flare line) with the most recent JSA occurring on September 21, 2006. Since maintenance procedures are task specific at the Memphis Refinery, review dates for JSA's were used to fulfill the maintenance procedures review criteria.  Operations along with HS&E Department personnel provide support to ensure that work is carried out safely.  Technical support is provided by the Process Engineering Group and the Project Engineering Group. 

Safe Work Practices

Premcor has longstanding safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include 1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, 2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, 3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials prior to opening process piping

or equipment, 4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and 5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.  These procedures (and others), along with training, help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are preformed safely.  The PSM database offers access to Refinery Safe Work Practices and Refinery Safety Policies and Procedures.   

The HS&E Department assumes overall responsibility for the development and enforcement of Refinery Safe Work Practices and Safety Policies and Procedures.  Front line enforcement of safe work practices are the responsibility of the area supervisors and craft foreman.  Premcor expects each employee be responsible for his or her own safety, as well as the safety of his or her coworkers.  

Management of Change

Any modification that creates a change in existing process safety information must go through a documented process of verification.  The management of change (MOC) process is a system of checks and balances intended to ensure that each department involved in the planning, installation, and operation of the modified process has reviewed the change.  The process also ensures that all affected process safety information is updated to reflect the change, and that the safety of the modification has been evaluated before startup.  

The management of change process is initiated when an originator fills out an MOC form, which describes the change and provides justification for the project.  The MOC form identifies and documents the following:

* The technical basis for the change
* The impact of the change on safety and health
* The necessary revisions to process safety information
* Completion of a pre-startup safety review
* Approval from the appropriate departments

The originator then secures approval from Operations, Maintenance, Engineering, and PSM managers to proceed with the project.  If the modification is a maj

or upgrade to a process unit, a HAZOP study may be initiated.  At this point, members of the HAZOP team may make recommendations to modify the original design or to correct safety concerns.  Upon completion of the project, a pre-startup safety review is conducted.  When all requirements have been met and all recommendations have been resolved, the new or modified equipment may be placed in service.
    
Any employee may initiate the MOC process.  Typically, the project or process engineer overseeing the change is responsible for verifying completion of the MOC process.  Managers over the Operations, Engineering, Maintenance, and PSM departments must document their approval of the change by signing the MOC form.  Other managers may be included in the approval process (reliability, inspection, environmental, etc.) depending on the change.  The HS&E Department has ultimate responsibility for verifying that work has been completed, the appropriate approval has been granted, all process safety information has been updated, and that all required documentation is completed, thus closing out the MOC process.

Incident Investigation and Event Notices

The policy of the Memphis Refinery is to promptly and thoroughly investigate PSM incidents, as well as events of a lesser nature.  Personnel are required to report incidents or events to the area supervisor, or other person in charge, the same day that they occur.  For each incident, the involved employee must fill out an event notice, which gives details concerning the incident.  The event notice is sent immediately to the HS&E Department and is transmitted across the refinery to all Memphis Refinery employees via the e-mail system.  Event notices are reviewed during the refinery morning meeting which includes all levels of management.  Incidents involving contract employees are reported using the same guidelines. 

The refinery Vice-President and General Manager, Operations Director, Maintenance Director, Technical Director o

r Director of HS&E makes the determination as to whether events classify as PSM incidents.  Those individuals also establish the makeup of the investigation team, which should involve at least one member from HS&E, the involved employee, and someone familiar with the process.  A formal report is presented and distributed at the conclusion of the investigation.  Each recommendation arising from the investigation is assigned to a responsible individual, entered into the refinery's recommendation tracking system, and followed until it is resolved.  The HS&E Department holds primary responsibility for administration of the event notice and incident investigation program.  The Department ensures that investigations are conducted according to policy and that employees are appropriately involved in the investigation.  It should be noted that investigations of non PSM incidents are also conducted by the refinery.

Emergency Planning and Response

The Memphis Refinery is required to establish and implement an emergency action plan to handle both large and small releases, to comply with federal law and to fulfill its responsibility to the community.  The plan must meet the requirements for employee emergency and fire prevention plans found in 29 CFR 1910.38 (a).  The Memphis Refinery's Emergency Response Plan (ERP) contains specific procedures for prompt response to emergencies that impact property and personnel inside. and outside the refinery.  Refinery personnel developed the plan in cooperation with the United States Coast Guard, the Memphis Fire Department, the Memphis-Shelby County Emergency Management Agency, and other local officials.  The plan specifies how the emergency is handled, including corrective procedures, coordination with outside response agencies, and communication with the public.  

Periodic compliance audits ensure that the plan is kept up-to-date. Copies of the plan are available at several locations, and an online version is accessible from the PSM d

atabase.  The Environmental Department shares responsibility for the ERP with the Safety Department.  The Safety Department coordinates training required by the plan. 

The Memphis refinery maintains a Fire Department with personnel trained to both incipient and fire fighter status (regular fire department personnel attend training at Texas A&M).  The Memphis Refinery Fire Department is recognized by the State of Tennessee as a certified fire department.  The refinery also maintains a HAZMAT team, an Oil Spill Response Team, a High Angle Rescue Team, and a Confined Space Entry Rescue Team.  Team members attend routine required training and meet OSHA requirements for emergency responders.

Compliance Audits

As required by the PSM standard, at least once every three years the refinery conducts a self audit in accordance with the compliance guidelines and enforcement procedures in OSHA Instruction CPL 2-2.45A.  The audit team includes at least one employee knowledgeable in the refinery and in the audit process.  At the conclusion of the audit, the audit team submits a draft report to the refinery vice-president and general manager for review.  Upon acceptance and within 45 days, a final report is released to the vice-president and general manager.  Refinery management returns appropriate responses to each finding in the report, and takes steps necessary to correct any deficiencies detected by the audit.  Upon resolution of the audit findings, the audit team and Safety Department sign the final report, certifying completion of the audit. As required by 29 CFR 1910.119(o), the Memphis Refinery retains the two most recent audit reports.  The compliance audit is the responsibility of the HS&E Department.  Additional audits (such as insurance or safety) are conducted on a routine basis.

The last PSM compliance audit for the facility was conducted July 14, 2006; therefore the date of the most recent compliance audit for the facility was used in section 7.10 of the program

for this unit.

Trade Secrets

The Memphis Refinery withholds no information necessary for employees to safely carry out their assigned job tasks.  However, refinery employees are required to enter into a confidentiality agreement as a condition of employment to protect trade secrets or other proprietary information.  The confidentiality agreement may also be required of contractors or contract employees, if necessary.  The HS&E Department conforms to this policy in its development and administration of the PSM program.

Recommendation Tracking

The Memphis Refinery has developed a tracking system to manage recommendations, MOC items, and other safety concerns arising as a result of PSM-related activities.  When a review team member makes a recommendation, it is recorded in the review documentation, and responsibility for evaluation and action is assigned.  The recommendation is entered into the appropriate section of the PSM database.  The team assigns a target date for resolution.  The responsible individual then decides whether the recommendation is valid and requires action, or if no action is necessary.  HS&E Department personnel administer the tracking system, periodically reviewing the status of a recommendation or MOC by performing a search in the PSM database.  A status report is provided to the leadership team.  All aspects of recommendation tracking, from generation to resolution, are available for review by any employee in the PSM database.  The database record may be searched according to:

* Source of the recommendation            * Unit or location
* Target date                    * Completion date
* Status                    * Priority
* Individual or departmental responsibility

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at Premcor involve hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program is applied to all RMP-covered processes at Premcor.  Collectively, these activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused

el of incident will typically involve outside agencies such as the Memphis Fire Dept., Emergency Management Agency, U.S. Coast Guard, etc.  A command center will be established as part of a Level II accident.
* Responsibilities of personnel assigned emergency response duties.  Duties are subdivided by the type of incident, the incident level, Incident Command positions, and pre-emergency, emergency, and post-emergency duties.
* Written procedures are included for fire incidents, HAZMAT incidents, Hydrofluoric Acid (HF) incidents, Hydrogen Sulfide incidents, and LPG incidents.  
* Fire incident procedures include sections for an exchanger fire, a process heater fire, and a pump fire.
* HF, Hydrogen Sulfide, and LPG response procedures include properties/hazards of the subsurface, essential protective equipment, and first aid measures.
* Guidelines for HAZMAT incidents, bomb threats, and civil disturbances.
* Decontamination procedures    
* Incident communication tools
* Evacuation plan and procedures to account for employees
* Emergency alarms
* Security
* Emergency phone numbers such as 911, fire, police, ambulance, Coast Guard, hospitals, and doctors

Employees receive annual training in various elements of safety, PSM and emergency response. The emergency response program is updated whenever necessary due to changes in the refinery processes or refinery facilities.  Any changes in the emergency response program are administered through the Management of Change (MOC) process.

The overall emergency response program for Premcor is coordinated with the Memphis-Shelby County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes monthly LEPC meetings, which consist of local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  Premcor conducts periodic emergency drills that involve local, state, and federal emergency response organizations, and the refinery provides refresher training to local emergency responders re

garding the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery.  The refinery participates actively in the LEPC and maintains good relations with area Fire Departments.  The refinery has 24-hour communications ability to notify appropriate emergency response organization in the event of an emergency.   Any public notifications will be coordinated through the Memphis-Shelby County Emergency Management Agency.   

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Premcor is committed to a high level of corporate citizenship, placing the highest priority on the safety of persons both within the refinery, and in the neighboring community.  The Memphis Refinery strives to continually improve the safety program, and to reward employees for outstanding safety performance.

Valero Energy Corporation has committed to having all their refineries (12 of the 16 domestic refineries are already STAR sites) meet the standards for OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program.  A plan is being formulated at the Memphis Refinery to move the refinery toward this goal.  This plan is supported by the Corporate VPP Coordinator.

Notes on RMP Information

Maximum inventories of RMP flammables in process units were estimated using a "conservative" technique that yields overstated process inventories.   

The largest inventory of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) in the refinery is found in the SRU, which was investigated to determine if an amount above the threshold quantity (10,000 lbs) of H2S was present.  It was determined that the amount of H2S in SRU#1, SRU#2, or elsewhere in the refinery did not exceed the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs for H2S.

Note:   September 2006, Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel Hydrotreater DHT-18- Startup Submission

RMP regulations require that a RMP update be submitted on or before the startup date of a new process.  Therefore, all data concerning DHT-18 in the September 2006, RMP submission was gathered prior to the startup.  Since the unit has not yet been operated, some of the projected operating
data may prove to be inaccurate.  Premcor will submit a corrected RMP if actual operating data varies significantly from the projections contained in the pre-startup submission.
